aboutSummit.title: <primary>The Regional Environmental Summit 2026</primary> aims to form a common vision for the sustainable development of Central Asia.
aboutSummit.text1: The Summit aims to unite Central Asian countries in partnership with the UN to develop agreed solutions to climate and environmental challenges. This is a two-year process (2024–2026) that has received broad international and political support. The Summit's concept is based on the idea of "Bir Tamyr" ("One Root") - a symbol of common heritage and collective action for a sustainable future of the region.
aboutSummit.text2: We live in an era when innovation and sustainable development are becoming the most important priorities. At our summit, you will be able to see how cutting-edge ideas and solutions can change the world for the better. We invite you to become part of this movement to build together a future that inspires and motivates.

programms.title: Program
programms.text: Every day at RES 2026 will bring inspiration, discoveries and opportunities for cooperation. Follow the most important moments and learn about unique events such as evening events, networking sessions and awards for the best innovative projects.

speakers.text: The best minds of our time will gather at RES 2026.
speakers.text1: We are proud to be able to present on our platform world leaders in technology, sustainable development and science. Our speakers are those who shape the future by making the most important decisions that change the world.

partners.text: RES 2026 would not have been possible without the support of our esteemed organizers, partners and media partners.
partners.text1: These leading companies and organizations play a key role in creating this unique event and allow us to present the most advanced ideas and technologies of world-class level.

connectionBanner.text: Join us at RES 2026 - a unique event that will become the center of innovation, technology and sustainable development!

footer.text: The Summit will be held at EXPO - International Exhibition Center, one of the country's main venues for world events and innovative projects.

about.title: About the summit
about.presidentText:
«Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN and other international organizations, will host the Regional Environmental Summit in Astana next April. 
 As part of our broader commitment to environmental protection, Kazakhstan is implementing the nationwide campaign «Taza Kazakhstan.» 

 This nationwide movement unites millions of volunteers who participate in cleanups, waste reduction, and environmental education.»
about.presidentInitiativeText:
"However, development cannot be sustainable without addressing the climate crisis. Central Asia is one of the regions most vulnerable to climate change on the planet. Warming here occurs twice as fast as the global average. In response, we are promoting a pragmatic and regionally coordinated climate agenda. Our commitments include participation in various international organizations and agreements. 

 In 2026, Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN, will hold a Regional Ecological Summit, which is intended to become a platform for uniting Central Asian strategies and global ambitions".
about.presidentPosition: From the speech of the President of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev at the general debate of the 80th session of the UN General Assembly, New York, USA
about.text2: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026, initiated by the President of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, aims to unite Central Asian countries in partnership with the UN to develop agreed solutions to climate and environmental challenges. This is a two-year process (2024–2026) that has received broad international and political support. The Summit's concept is based on the idea of "Bir Tamyr" ("One Root") - a symbol of common heritage and collective action for a sustainable future of the region.
about.text3: The 2026 Regional Environmental Summit, in partnership with the UN, will bring together Central Asian countries to develop coordinated solutions on climate and the environment, including topics such as preserving the Aral Sea and shrinking the Caspian Sea basin, promoting green finance and low-carbon technologies, and developing joint initiatives, declarations, and an Action Program for 2026–2030 for the region's sustainable development.
about.aboutText1: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev and aims to unite Central Asian countries to develop common solutions to combat climate change in partnership with the UN. This is not just a meeting - it is a two-year preparation process that started in 2024 and culminates in a high-level Summit in 2026, where agreed environmental initiatives and mechanisms for regional cooperation will be presented.
about.aboutText2: The United Nations expressed its support for the Summit in General Assembly Resolution 78/147 of 19 December 2023, “Central Asia Facing Environmental Challenges: Strengthening Regional Solidarity for Sustainable Development and Prosperity.”
about.aboutText3: Support for the initiative was also enshrined in a number of key political documents at the level of heads of state:
about.aboutText31: Karabakh Declaration of the Informal Summit of the Organization of Turkic States (July 6, 2024, Azerbaijan);
about.aboutText32: Joint Statement of the Sixth Consultative Meeting of Heads of State of Central Asia (August 9, 2024, Kazakhstan);
about.aboutText33: Bishkek Declaration of the Eleventh Summit of the Organization of Turkic States (November 6, 2024, Kyrgyz Republic).
about.aboutText34:
In 2025, this initiative was further recognized during the opening ceremony of the UN Regional Hub for Sustainable Development Goals for Central Asia and Afghanistan, attended by UN Secretary-General António Guterres, and the Third UN Conference on Landlocked Developing Countries (Turkmenistan). 

 The 2026 REC aims to unite the countries of Central Asia to develop common solutions to combat climate change and overcome environmental challenges in partnership with the UN and international organizations. Particular attention will be paid to identifying the real needs of Central Asia for green financing aimed at supporting adaptation measures, developing low-carbon technologies, and strengthening the region's environmental resilience. The summit creates a regional platform for dialogue and solidarity, strengthening cooperation between states, international organizations, academia, and business. It promotes awareness of priority environmental issues, the search for practical solutions, and the development of joint action plans for the future aimed at the sustainable development of the region.
about.aboutText4:
"However, development cannot be sustainable without addressing the climate crisis. Central Asia is one of the regions most vulnerable to climate change on the planet. Warming here occurs twice as fast as the global average. In response, we are promoting a pragmatic and regionally coordinated climate agenda. Our commitments include participation in various international organizations and agreements. 

 In 2026, Kazakhstan, in partnership with the UN, will hold a Regional Ecological Summit, which is intended to become a platform for uniting Central Asian strategies and global ambitions".
about.aboutText5:
The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 in partnership with the UN is a platform for uniting Central Asian countries in developing agreed working solutions and mechanisms that reflect a regional approach to overcoming climate and environmental challenges, including the tragedy of the Aral Sea, which has become a global symbol of environmental degradation, and the steady decline in the level of the Caspian Sea. Special attention will be paid to the formation of real needs of Central Asia in 'green' financing aimed at supporting adaptation measures, developing low-carbon technologies and strengthening the environmental sustainability of the region. 

 The Summit creates a regional platform for dialogue and solidarity, strengthening cooperation between states, international organizations, scientific and business communities. It contributes to raising awareness of priority environmental issues, finding practical solutions and forming joint action plans for the future aimed at sustainable development of the region. The goal is to form specific initiatives and mechanisms for joint action. Adoption of the Joint Declaration of Heads of State of Central Asia on regional cooperation in ecology and sustainable development. 

 Approval of the Regional Action Program with UN agencies (2026–2030) for a sustainable future of Central Asia, including regional initiatives on thematic areas of the Summit, launch of new environmental projects and initiatives in the directions of the Summit. Preparation for the summit began in 2024 and includes a series of regional consultations. The Summit will be the culmination of this process and will give political impetus to the environmental agenda of the region. The initiative strengthens the existing efforts of countries, complementing them with a regional dimension. The basis will be a coordinated environmental agenda, including updated climate goals of Central Asian countries.
about.resText1: The Regional Ecological Summit 2026 was initiated by the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan Kassym-Jomart Tokayev on the 78th Session of the UN General Assembly in September 2023, and on the Astana International Forum in May 2025 it was announced that the agenda was expanded from climate to environmental.
about.resText2: At the center of the initiative is the idea of "Bir Tamyr" (One Root). The word "tamyr" exists in almost all the region's languages ​and carries a profound image: the roots of nature, the veins of the earth, the vessels of culture. It is a metaphor for connection, sustainability, and a shared heritage that unites Central Asia not by political borders, but by meaning, memory, and future. The summit reflects this image: one region—common challenges—collective action. It will unite states, international organizations, the scientific community, businesses, civil society, and youth to lay the foundation for a shared, environmentally sustainable future.

region.aboutKazakhstanText1:
Kazakhstan is the largest country in the world that does not have direct access to the World Ocean. Most of the country's territory is made up of deserts – 44% and semi-deserts-14%. Steppes occupy 26% of the area of Kazakhstan, forests-5.5%. There are 8,5 thousand rivers in the country. 

 The north-eastern part of the Caspian Sea is part of the republic. The Aral Sea is divided between Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan. There are 48 thousand large and small lakes in Kazakhstan. The largest of them are Balkhash, Zaisan and Alakol. The distance from the oceans determines the sharply continental climate of the country. 

 The administrative and territorial structure of the country includes
region.climateText2: Is sharply continental, with large temperature fluctuations between summer and winter, dry air and low precipitation. All four seasons are pronounced here: cold winters, hot dry summers, short and changeable spring, and warm autumn. In the north, winters are harsher and summers are warmer; in the south, winters are milder (near zero) and summers are hotter
region.floraAndFaunaText1: The flora and fauna of Kazakhstan
region.floraAndFaunaText2: is extremely diverse due to its large natural areas: from steppes and deserts to the Tien Shan and Altai Mountains, where there are unique species, many of which are in the Red Book, such as the snow leopard (snow leopard), Tianshan brown bear, kulan, as well as pink flamingos, gazelles. It is home to many mammals (more than 180 species), birds (about 500 species), reptiles, amphibians and fish, and vegetation includes saxaul, juniper, pine, birch and many steppe grasses and flowers, reflecting the richness of biodiversity.

etc.strategicVisionIntro: Kazakhstan has adopted the following strategic documents:

strategicDocuments.0: Strategy for achieving carbon neutrality by 2060. Roadmap to the strategy
strategicDocuments.1: IT AMS to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 17% from 1990 levels by 2035
strategicDocuments.2: Concept for the transition of the Republic of Kazakhstan to a 'green economy'
strategicDocuments.3: Concept for the management of all types of waste for 2026–2030
strategicDocuments.4: Concept for the conservation and sustainable use of biodiversity for the period 2025–2035

etc.tazaKazakhstanText: A large-scale national environmental campaign under the auspices of the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan K. Tokayev, aimed at forming an environmental culture through cleaning territories (settlements, natural objects, shores of water bodies), planting trees (millions of seedlings) and fighting unauthorized dumps, with the involvement of youth, business and government agencies, with an emphasis on waste management, innovation and improvement.
etc.twoBillionTreesText: An initiative in Kazakhstan aimed at creating forest areas by 2025 with subsequent extension until 2027. The goal of the project is to plant and sow 2 billion seedlings of tree and shrub species, including saxaul, pine, birch and others, in the state forest fund to restore forests and improve the environmental situation.
etc.biodiversityFundText: Kazakhstan's initiative, uniting the efforts of states, international organizations (UNDP, UNESCO, FAO) and NGOs to finance the protection of ecosystems, develop ecotourism, introduce eco-technologies and raise awareness in accordance with the best international standards of sustainable development and conservation of flora and fauna.
etc.unRegionalCenterTitle: The UN Regional Center for Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) for Central Asia and Afghanistan was established in Kazakhstan (Almaty).
etc.unRegionalCenterText: It was approved by UN member states in March 2025, opened in August 2025 and is aimed at facilitating the achievement of 17 global SDGs by 2030.
